title: Memory leak inside ExntesionService::Init in Linux/CrOS ui tests

sentences.text: This started around r43162 on all the Valgrind bots.
40 (24 direct, 16 indirect) bytes in 1 blocks are definitely lost in loss  record 763 of 1,030
40 (24 direct, 16 indirect) bytes in 1 blocks are definitely lost in loss  record 762 of 1,030
I had to slightly widen the suppression: http://codereview.chromium.org/1515010.
Giving to rafaelw because his  CL definitely caused this.
The following revision refers to this bug:
Suppress an extension init memory leak.
The following revision refers to this bug:
Widen a suppression for a leak in ExntesionService::Init().
I've done some investigation here and also recruited eric's help trying to figure out  what's going
Though this leak clearly started with my checkin, the underlying issue is  http://codereview.chromium.org/1023004.
The upshot is that the CookieMonster::Delegate's profile_getter_ is being leaked.
It's not clear to why this has begun with my CL, but it seems as though the  CookieMonster::Delegate::ProfileGetter is being leaked because it has the  DeleteOnUIThread trait,
but in all likelihood, the PostTask to the UI thread to delete the object (and  deregister the
PROFILE_DESTROYED notification) isn't happening because the browser is being shut  down.
Eric has suggested that the right thing to do here is remove the DeleteOnUIThread  trait and not
worry about potentially failing to deregister for the notification.
approach, but since this is jochen's code, I'm going to let him handle it.
Yeah, so I think the problem here is that ProfileGetter is refcounted, and marked as DeleteOnUIThread.

So if the final reference to ProfileGetter is released during shutdown while Thread::Stop() is being called on the  IOThread, then it will post a release task to the UI thread, however this task will never actually get run (because  we are shutting down).
Not clear to me what the best fix is, it is ugly.
I guess the main problem is that somebody keeps a ref to the url request context getter and never frees it (where never is beyond the lifetime of the profile)...
you could argue that this is the real bug.
There were also quite a lot of leaks in unit tests because many unit tests use the profile without an ui thread (which is a bug imho as well)
I'll try to fix this tomorrow by adding a trait class that deletes on UI thread, if UI thread still exists or immediately otherwise.
I had a closer look, and this is not the ProfileGetter who's at fault here.
The UI thread outlives the IO thread, and therefore, the profilegetter is always  correctly deleted in chrome.
However, unit tests don't necessarily have IO and UI threads.
If you introduce stuff  that has objects living on these threads (url request context getters for example),  you need to create the threads in the unit tests.
(and make sure the message loop is  cleared at the end of the test).
So the two options are (a) fix the unit tests (b) go with the suppression.
Once again, it seems like the two options are (a) do the right thing (b) do the easy  thing =-(.
Then again, I don't know very much about the UI test framework.
browser tests must  always fire up all the threads.
Maybe it's ok to just have a suppression and assume  that over time ui tests get migrated to browser tests.
(No comment was entered for this change.)
My take on this is that the leak here only exists in the tests (because of the thread  existence differences), so its fine to just live with the suppression.
However, in a certain sense, it seems better to have the test harness more closely  match the browser runtime, but i think that's a different issue (and not one I'm  qualified to tackle).
(No comment was entered for this change.)
Since no one else has weighed on this, I'm going to assume it's fine to live with the  suppression because the issue is only present in the test harness.
